docs.lead_paragraph: While the F.D.A. can see what kinds of antibiotic-resistant bacteria are coming out of livestock facilities, the agency knows little about the antibiotics that are being fed to the animals.

headline.main: Antibiotics and the Meat We Eat
headline.print_headline: Antibiotics and the Meat We Eat

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by David A Kessler, commissioner of Food and Drug Administration from 1990 to 1997, warns that FDA knows little about antibiotics that are being fed to livestock; calls on lawmakers to pass measure that will require food producers to disclose how often they feed antibiotics to animals at low levels.
docs.snippet: While the F.D.A. can see what kinds of antibiotic-resistant bacteria are coming out of livestock facilities, the agency knows little about the antibiotics that are being fed to the animals.

docs.abstract: Consumers tend to dislike the idea of rationing, but would it be better than the alternatives?
docs.snippet: Consumers tend to dislike the idea of rationing, but would it be better than the alternatives?

docs.lead_paragraph: A visitor from Papua New Guinea was Australia’s first death from the disease, a fact that has alarmed health officials and added heat to a debate over how to treat immigrants with dangerous illnesses.

headline.seo: Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis Knocks at Australia’s Door
headline.main: Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis Knocks at Australia’s Door

docs.abstract: Australia’s first death from XDR-TB, extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis that has taken hold on island of Daru and is nearly incurable, has alarmed health officials and added heat to debate over how to treat immigrants with dangerous diseases.
docs.snippet: A visitor from Papua New Guinea was Australia’s first death from the disease, a fact that has alarmed health officials and added heat to a debate over how to treat immigrants with dangerous illnesses.

docs.lead_paragraph:
The government recommended years ago that all adolescent girls get a vaccine to protect against cervical cancer . But nearly seven years after it first came to market, an overwhelming majority of girls have yet to be inoculated.
 
Just 35 percent of girls 13 to 17 have received a full course of the vaccine, which inoculates against the strains of human papillomavirus that can cause cervical cancer, according to 2011 data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. And a study in Pediatrics this month , also based on C.D.C. data, says the intent to vaccinate is declining: 44 percent of parents in 2010 said they did not intend to vaccinate, up from 40 percent in 2008.
docs.snippet:
The government recommended years ago that all adolescent girls get a vaccine to protect against  cervical cancer . But nearly seven years after it first came to market, an overwhelming majority of girls have yet to be inoculated.

docs.abstract: Health professionals hope to make the shots more accessible, and to make the vaccine sound less scary to parents and daughters.
docs.snippet: Health professionals hope to make the shots more accessible, and to make the vaccine sound less scary to parents and daughters.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 100 physicians have been killed and hundreds more have disappeared into Syrian jails in the last two years.

headline.seo: On Both Sides in Syrian War, Doctors Are Often the Target
headline.main: In Syria’s Civil War, Doctors Find Themselves in Cross Hairs
headline.print_headline: In Syria’s Civil War, Doctors Find Themselves in Cross Hairs

docs.abstract: More than 100 Syrian physicians have been killed and hundreds more have disappeared in jails in last two years due to government suspecting that they have been treating rebels.
docs.snippet: More than 100 physicians have been killed and hundreds more have disappeared into Syrian jails in the last two years.
